error.regex: (?i)(?:Return code is: 403|403.*Forbidden.*deploy|Failed to deploy artifacts|authorization failed.*repository)

verdict.summary: Maven deploy/publish returned 403 Forbidden from the artifact repository. Common causes: incorrect credentials in settings.xml, insufficient permissions on the repository, attempting to overwrite a released (non-SNAPSHOT) artifact, or repository policy rejecting the upload.

dead_ends.why_fails: Most repositories (Maven Central, Nexus, Artifactory) forbid overwriting released artifacts. A 403 for released versions is permanent unless the artifact is explicitly deleted first.

dead_ends.action: Adding credentials to pom.xml instead of settings.xml
dead_ends.why_fails: Maven ignores server credentials in pom.xml. Credentials must be in ~/.m2/settings.xml or passed via environment variables. Also, credentials in pom.xml get committed to version control.

workarounds.action: Configure server credentials in settings.xml matching the distributionManagement server ID
workarounds.how: Ensure the <server> block ID in settings.xml matches the <repository>/<snapshotRepository> ID in pom.xml. In CI, use MAVEN_USERNAME and MAVEN_PASSWORD environment variables with the maven-settings-action or set up settings.xml via secrets.

workarounds.action: Bump the version for a new release or use -SNAPSHOT suffix
workarounds.how: If the error occurs because the version already exists, bump the version in pom.xml. For iterative development, use SNAPSHOT versions (e.g., 1.2.3-SNAPSHOT) which allow overwrites.

leads_to.condition: when automated versioning and publishing pipelines encounter repository permissions issues

preceded_by.condition: when Maven credentials environment variables are not set in CI

frequently_confused_with.distinction: maven-publish-403 is about artifact publishing permissions; npm-audit-critical is about dependency vulnerability scanning failures
